p.s: In the given extract one can find many means of language used to show how Romeo and Juliet think about their love and express it, and how they deal with their love's difficult circumstancecircumstance's.

Juliet is much more worried and timid than Romeo; she asks him questions or asks him to confess her love as well to know that what she does is worth it, as shown in (l. 90) Dost thou love me? and continued in (ll. 92-93) Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries They say, love laughs, which shows much better how worried she is, that her love isn't reciprocated.

She is also scared that Romeo is found by her family in their orchard; she warns him several times, such as in (ll. 64f) And the place death, considering who thou art, if any of my kinsmen find thee here and already expresses her love through wanting him safe (l. 74) I would not for the world they saw thee here.
When Juliet refers back to a monologue she held earlier in the scene, she is apologetic about it yet cannot deny it.
She takes a risk by saying that she gives up the convention and therefore their family feud as well (l. 85) but farewell compliment if Romeo was to love her as well.
Romeo on the other hand is bold and foolish.

Not just his action, coming to the orchard, shows this, but also the hyperboles he uses when Juliet tries to warn him, such as with love's light wings did I o'er-perch these walls in (l. 66), which also includes a metaphor and an alliteration, giving his expressiosn a feeling of lovesickness or toverunkeness that makes everything appear to be dramatic and poetic, just as alliterations and metaphors do, and (ll. 72-73) look thou but sweet, and I am proof against their enmity.
Romeo does not take the danger he is in seriously or doesn't care about it since he is so infatuated by his love for Juliet.
He also allures to their familiesfamilies' rivalry and how their love is stronger by denying his family and himself if Juliet was not fond of either or both (l. 61).
Romeo and Juliet both speak openly about their love for eachother.
Romeo more than Juliet as though they can't deny it.
The word love itself is often found such as in (l. 66,77,80,94,111) and more.

That their love is under unusual circumstances like knowing eachother for such a short time or coming from rivaling families is also shown by the contrasts used in the extract: Juliet starts by saying My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound (ll. 58-59) showing that even after only such a short time Romeo is so dear to Juliet.
This adds legitemacy to their love for the viewer, who takes this play in even more quickly than time goes by within the play and needs to believe in their love.
That Romeo is aware of the conflicting situation they are in yet does not care about it is shown in (l. 77-78).
My life were better ended by their hate, than death prorogued, wanting of thy love.
This contrast shows how the love between them, despite the circumstances of hate, is stronger than it.
This also makes their love more believable but also more dramatic, both engaging the viewer.

That both of them are infatuated with eachother is also shown to the audience by their register: Theythey compliment eachother fair saint (l. 61) gentle Romeo (l. 93) and speak in an endearing way of eachother.

The tone of romance in the scene also lies in the metaphors, alliterations, rhymes and siliber in their speech; all of these stylistic devices work with imagery or sound building an atmosphere for the reader to undersand and feel the love displayed.
Repeatedly the night is referedreferred to in metaphors night's cloak (l. 75), mask of night (l. 85).
Both times the night is hiding Romeo and Juliet, keeping them of getting caught by Juliet's relatives or eachother.
These metaphors don't just have the previous mentioned effect but also allure to their ongoing romance that only allows them to meet at night.
The moon, which is mentioned first in (l. 107) is a reaccuringreoccuring motive throughout the play as well.
Rhymes can be found in (l. 61) or (ll. 86-87).
A strong silibe can be found in (ll. 82-84) I am not a pilot; yet, wert thou as far as that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.
Not just does it say that Romeo would've taken a great distance onto him in order to seasee Juliet, but the sea also represents danger, especially after Romeo declares that he is not a sailor.
It also compliments Juliet again, her being metaphorically the treasure in this comparison.
This also proves to the audience how strong Romeo's love for Juliet is and makes love as a motive for his future actions believable to the viewer.
